Posts.Content: If you have to have Chemotherapy - try using Scalp Cooling - I had 12 weeks of Taxol and kept my hair throughout - although I did loose half my half my hair after starting on AC chemo - but it was totally worth it to keep my hair for a lot longer than the doctors said I would - the doctor was always surprised to see that I still had my hair during the 12 weeks I was getting the taxol and my hair stayed until the day before my second AC chemo. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Just Getting Started on this Journey

Posts.Content: Thanks boc0913 for the prayers and the advice!  Hope your recovery is swift!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Had additional spot mammography Friday- scheduled for ultrasound guided needle biopsy Thursday - still freaked out but working on trying to calm down!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you - yes I believe in MD Anderson - my friends mother had breast cancer over 25 years ago and she went to MD Anderson - she's still alive and kicking butt :) Thank you for your encouraging words - please accept my prayers for your husband!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Consulted with Oncologist and he said there were only a few cells in my lymph nodes and he considered that negative so wouldn't bother taking out my lymph nodes. Yay! He did say I would need chemo because me tumor was so large.  Had more tissue removed and at the end of the month I go back to have an echocardiogram, bone scan and a CT scan, then see the oncologist again - so I guess I will find out my treatment plan then.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for the suggestions! I have already started stocking up! Hope you are doing well!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thanks Nat!  I do read statistics and appreciate you relating all the information that you have.  Hope you do well with your treatment!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi!  I did get to MD Anderson, had a segmental masectomy, reduction and lift last monday, and feeling great.  Just waiting for biopsy results from the sentinel node.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thanks Nat!  I do read statistics and appreciate you relating all the information that you have.  Hope you do well with your treatment!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi, I've been freaking out for a few days now - had my screening mammogram on Jan 2 (missed having it for almost 2 years) and the tech asked to take another picture of my left breast.  Later that night I thought it was a little odd and proceeded to do my self exam (which I also had been lax on for the last couple of months) and I noticed a thick feeling section in my left breast (I'm 53, obese, and have breast fed two kids in my late 30's, so my breast are pretty floppy and soft) - so it freaked me out.  My GYN visit was on the 7th, the Dr. said she couldnt feel anything but would look at the mammogram report -.  she sent the nurse out to tell me that the mammagram center wanted me to come back in for some additional reviews on my left breast. My sister had breast cancer at 42.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thanks Hussy!  I am trying to remain calm - I seem to not be very good at it!  :)
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you! Biopsy went well -now just have to wait for the results! Thank you for you kind thoughts! Still hoping for something benign.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you - the nurse navigator said see a surgeon then an oncologist - but the hospital where I had my biopsy doesnt have the best reputation so I'm trying to get an appointment at MD Anderson in Houston (I live in the Dallas/Ft Worth area) since they are the premier cancer treatment hospital in the state.  Hopefully it won't take long to get in - although the cancer center was closed today for MLK day. Thank you for you assistance and I hope your recovery goes well!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Just heard that I had micrometasis in my sentinel node which they said they still have to call a positive node and my tumor was larger than they thought (10 cm).  Waiting for word from surgeon if I will require more surgery or additional lymph node dissection.  Not the news I was hoping for.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you!  I'm trying to stay positive and most the time it works.  Saw my surgeon yesterday and will require additional surgery to remove more tissue so that the clear margin is wider. Radiation oncologist wants to use radiation to kill the little bit of cancer in my sentinel node, surgeon agrees but wants the breast oncologist to decide.  I'm hoping to save my lymph nodes cause I watched my sister suffer the effects of lymph node removal - she could barely use her left arm. But of course I will do what needs to be done to make sure the cancer is eradicated :) Thank you all for your kind support!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you for the advice and prayers!  I hope everything works out well for you also!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for the suggestions! I have already started stocking up! Hope you are doing well!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: I forgot to add, that I've had an ache in my breast and left armpit since the mammogram.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Went for my diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound today - the radiologist said there is increased density in the area from two years ago (sure stood out on the mammogram) - the ultrasound took forever - there is something there and the technician had a hard time finding anything in the area - the radialogist came in and helped her and took lots more pictures including some under my armpit (that's worrying).  The radiologist said there is something there but couldnt definately say if it was a tumore or just dense tissue - Going for a biopsy next thursday.
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Well it wasn't bengin- Invasive Lobular Carcinoma G1-2. Hoping that means early detection!
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Update- had my segmental masectomy with a reduction and lift today along with a Sentinel node biopsy- only removed one node and will get the results back next week
Posts.Title: Freaking Out after mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Ebusy!  I started chemotherapy on May 14 with Taxol.  I started using the scalp cooling system in my local area.  I just finished the 12 weekly doses of Taxol last week and to date I still have most of my hair - a little thining on top but not very noticible.  I started AC chemo yesterday so I'm waiting to see if the cold cap system holds up to that drug regimen.  I say its definately worth it to try it - you can always stop if your hair falls out but I'd rather take the chance it stays.  Hope this reached you in time to help with your decision.  good luck!   Lisa G.
Posts.Title: Penguin cold cap use

Posts.Content: I'm almost through chemo (2 more AC's to go) so now I'm thinking about my radiation.  I had micrometasis in the sentinel node and my surgeon, oncologist and radiation oncologist said they could treat it with radiation instead of removing all my lymph nodes (I agreed).  I was wondering if anyone here had undergone axillary radiation and have you suffered from lymphedema, fibrosis in the shoulder, or shoulder nerve damage (some of the side affects)?   Thanks Lisa
Posts.Title: Axiallary Radiation

Posts.Content: I highly recommend MD Anderson in Houston TX.  I don't know of any particular doctor that specialized in metastized lobular carcinoma but its a good place.  I was diagnosed with Stage IIIA lobular carinoma earlier this year, so far I don't have any metastasis but I do recommend the hospital.  Ive seen a Dr. Ibriham and I've liked him the two whole times I've seen him so far - I've taken my chemo in my hometown but had I been able to I would have done it at MD Anderson - couldn't afford to be away from home and work for the 6 months of my chemo. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Doctor needed
